key_points: Texas regulators approved a plan to raise gas bills to pay $3.4 billion to gas companies for winter storm-related profits.
The payment covers unexpected debt from skyrocketing gas prices during February's winter storm and blackout.
The cost may be added to Texans' gas bills for up to 30 years.
The move by the Railroad Commission of Texas is part of a process known as securitization, approved by state legislators last spring.
Securitization aims to spread out the financial impact on consumers by converting debt into low-interest bonds paid over decades.
During the winter storm, gas prices surged, leading to massive profits for gas companies and accusations of price gouging.
It remains unclear how much monthly bills will increase for individual ratepayers as a result of the securitization.
Critics accused state lawmakers and the Railroad Commission of prioritizing gas company profits over consumer needs.
Virginia Palacios and Doug Lewin critiqued the commission's handling of the situation and potential future risks.
Governor Greg Abbott criticized for receiving a $1 million campaign contribution from Kelcy Warren, CEO of Energy Transfer Partners.
spokespersons: Paula Gold-Williams (Former Head, San Antonio’s Publicly Owned Utility)
